name: DECISON PROCESSES

values.comments:
This course is an intensive introduction to various scientific perspectives on the processes through which people make decisions. Perspectives covered include cognitive psychology of human problem-solving, judgment and choice, theories of rational judgment and decision, and the mathematical theory of games. Much of the material is technically rigorous. Prior or current enrollment in STAT 101 or the equivalent, although not required, is strongly recommended.

Students seemed to enjoy this “laid back” class. This class was deemed “intellectually stimulating while not exceptionally difficult.” Overall, the class seemed to be research driven and students generally liked the format.

Professor Simonsohn was “insightful” and “truly receptive about the needs of his students.” He kept the class entertaining and had a “mastery of his field.” Some students, however, felt that he needed to slow down his sentences due to his accent. Taken as a whole, the students found Professor Simonsohn extremely helpful and a “great teacher.”

In general, students agree that this class doesn’t have much reading or work, and that most of the work is done in groups. Students found the exams “a bit weird” as they were computerized. Professor Simonsohn was seen as a “fair grader.”
